title: 010 Android Internal and External Storage - Terminology Clarification

Android developers(mainly beginners) have been confused regarding Internal & External storage terminology. There are lot of questions on Stackoverflow regarding the same. This is mainly because of the fact that
terminology
i
according to Google/official Android documentation is quite different to that of normal Android OS user. Hence I thought documenting this would help.

inline_content.Text: Android developers(mainly beginners) have been confused regarding Internal & External storage terminology. There are lot of questions on Stackoverflow regarding the same. This is mainly because of the fact that
according to Google/official Android documentation is quite different to that of normal Android OS user. Hence I thought documenting this would help.

title:
Internal storage(UT)| External storage(UT)|
—— | —— |
phone’s inbuilt internal memory| removable Secure Digital(SD) card or micro SD storage|

Nexus 6P’s 32 GB internal memory.|

title: By default, files saved to the internal storage are private to your application and other applications cannot access them (nor can the user).

inline_content.Text: By default, files saved to the internal storage are private to your application and other applications cannot access them (nor can the user).

title: This can be a removable storage media (such as an SD card) or an internal (non-removable) storage.

inline_content.Text: This can be a removable storage media (such as an SD card) or an internal (non-removable) storage.

title: External Storage(GT) = Internal Storage(UT) and External Storage(UT)
b

inline_content.Text: External Storage(GT) = Internal Storage(UT) and External Storage(UT)

title: Internal Storage(GT) doesn’t have a term in UT.
b

inline_content.Text: Internal Storage(GT) doesn’t have a term in UT.

title: Internal Storage(GT):
b

By default, files saved to the internal storage are private to your application and other applications cannot access them. Your app user also can’t access them using file manager; even after enabling “show hidden files” option in file manager. To access files in Internal Storage(GT), you have to root your Android phone. Moreover, when the user uninstalls your application, these files are removed/deleted.

inline_content.Text: By default, files saved to the internal storage are private to your application and other applications cannot access them. Your app user also can’t access them using file manager; even after enabling “show hidden files” option in file manager. To access files in Internal Storage(GT), you have to root your Android phone. Moreover, when the user uninstalls your application, these files are removed/deleted.

title: So Internal Storage(GT) is
NOT
b
what we think as Nexus 6P’s 32/64 GB internal memory

inline_content.Text: what we think as Nexus 6P’s 32/64 GB internal memory

title: Every Android-compatible device supports a shared “external storage” that you can use to save files. Files saved to the external storage are world-readable and can be modified by the user when they enable USB mass storage to transfer files on a computer.

inline_content.Text: Every Android-compatible device supports a shared “external storage” that you can use to save files. Files saved to the external storage are world-readable and can be modified by the user when they enable USB mass storage to transfer files on a computer.

title: External Storage(GT) location:
b
It could be
anywhere
i
in your internal storage(UT) or in your removable storage(GT) i.e. micro SD card. It depends on your phone’s OEM and also on Android OS version.

inline_content.Text: in your internal storage(UT) or in your removable storage(GT) i.e. micro SD card. It depends on your phone’s OEM and also on Android OS version.

title: In order to read or write files on the External Storage(GT), your app must acquire the
READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE
c
or
WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE
c
system permissions.

inline_content.Text: In order to read or write files on the External Storage(GT), your app must acquire the

title: If you need to both read and write files, then you need to request only the WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permission, because it implicitly requires read access as well.

inline_content.Text: If you need to both read and write files, then you need to request only the WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permission, because it implicitly requires read access as well.

External Storage(GT)
b

app-private

inline_content.Text: When the user uninstalls your application, this directory and all its contents are deleted.

app-private

in

title: If you are handling files that are not intended for other apps to use (such as graphic textures or sound effects used by only your app), you should use a private storage directory on the external storage

inline_content.Text: If you are handling files that are not intended for other apps to use (such as graphic textures or sound effects used by only your app), you should use a private storage directory on the external storage

title: Beginning with Android 4.4, reading or writing files in your app’s private directories does not require the READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE or WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permissions. So you can declare the permission should be requested only on the lower versions of Android by adding the maxSdkVersion attribute:

inline_content.Text: Beginning with Android 4.4, reading or writing files in your app’s private directories does not require the READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE or WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permissions. So you can declare the permission should be requested only on the lower versions of Android by adding the maxSdkVersion attribute:

b

title: Officially, one method was introduced in
Context
c
class in API level 19 (Android version 4.4 - Kitkat).

inline_content.Text: Officially, one method was introduced in
class in API level 19 (Android version 4.4 - Kitkat).

title: It returns absolute paths to application-specific directories on all shared/external storage devices where the application can place persistent files it owns. These files are internal to the application, and not typically visible to the user as media.

inline_content.Text: It returns absolute paths to application-specific directories on all shared/external storage devices where the application can place persistent files it owns. These files are internal to the application, and not typically visible to the user as media.

title: That means, it will return paths to
both
b
types of External Storage(GT) - Internal memory and Micro SD card. Generally
second path
b
would be storage path of micro SD card(but not always). So you need to check it out by executing the code with this method.

types of External Storage(GT) - Internal memory and Micro SD card. Generally
would be storage path of micro SD card(but not always). So you need to check it out by executing the code with this method.

title: I created a new android project with empty activity, wrote the following code inside

title:
internal_m1: /data/data/your.application.package.appname/app_custom

internal_m2: /data/data/your.application.package.appname/files

external_m1: /storage/emulated/0

external_m2: /storage/emulated/0/Android/data/your.application.package.appname/files

external_m2_Args: /storage/emulated/0/Android/data/your.application.package.appname/files/Pictures

external_m3: /storage/emulated/0/Pictures

external_AND_removable_storage_m1 (first path):
/storage/emulated/0/Android/data/your.application.package.appname/files

external_AND_removable_storage_m1 (second path):    
/storage/sdcard1/Android/data/your.application.package.appname/files

 external_AND_removable_storage_m1_Args (first path):
/storage/emulated/0/Android/data/your.application.package.appname/files/Pictures

external_AND_removable_storage_m1_Args (second path): /storage/sdcard1/Android/data/your.application.package.appname/files/Pictures
